facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1953 arises from the judgment and decree dated July 14, 1948 of the Chief Court of Oudh, Lucknow

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1953, Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 14, 1948 of the

facts.text: Chief Court of Oudh decreed in Second Appeal No. 365 of 1945 on July 14, 1948

anchor.surface_text: decree dated May 30, 1945 of the Court of District Judge, Sitapur in Appeal No. 4 of 1945 against the decree dated November 25, 1944 of the Court of Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur in Regular Civil Suit No. 14 of 1944.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 4, 1956 by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. October 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-The point for decision in this appeal

facts.text: Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji is located in village Bhadesia, District Sitapur

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in the village of Bhadesia in the District of Sitapur is a private temple or a public one

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam constructed the Thakurdwara during 1914-1916

anchor.surface_text: One Sheo Ghulam, a pious Hindu and a resident of the said village, had the Thakurdwara constructed during the years 1914-1916, and the idol of Shri Radhakrishnaji ceremoniously installed therein.

facts.text: Idol of Shri Radhakrishnaji was ceremoniously installed in the Thakurdwara

anchor.surface_text: 1914-1916, and the idol of Shri Radhakrishnaji ceremoniously installed therein. He was himself in management of the temple and its affairs till 1928 when he died without any issue.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam managed the temple till 1928 when he died without issue

anchor.surface_text: installed therein. He was himself in management of the temple and its affairs till 1928 when he died without any issue. On March 6, 1919, he had executed a will whereby he bequeathed all his lands

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam executed a will on March 6, 1919 bequeathing all lands to the Thakur

anchor.surface_text: he died without any issue. On March 6, 1919, he had executed a will whereby he bequeathed all his lands to the Thakur. The provisions of the will, in so far as they are material, will presently be referred to.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam had two wives: Ram Kuar predeceased him, Raj Kuar survived and managed as Mutawalli till 1933

anchor.surface_text: The testator had two wives one of whom Ram Kuar, had predeceased him and the surviving widow, Raj Kuar, succeeded him as Mutawalli in terms of the will and was in management. till her death in 1933.

facts.text: First defendant, nephew of Sheo Ghulam, got possession as manager after Raj Kuar's death

anchor.surface_text: till her death in 1933. Then the first defendant who is the nephew of Sheo Ghulam, got into possession of the properties as manager of the endowment in accordance with the provisions of the will.

facts.text: Appellant is a distant agnate of Sheo Ghulam

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a distant agnate of Sheo Ghulam, and on the allegation that the first defendant had been mismanaging the temple and denying the rights of the public therein,

facts.text: Appellant applied to District Court Sitapur under Religious and Charitable Endowments Act XIV of 1920, court declined as private endowment

anchor.surface_text: he moved the District Court of Sitapur for relief under the Religious and Charitable Endowments Act XIV of 1920, but the court declined to interfere on the ground that the endowment was private.

facts.text: Application to Advocate-General for sanction under section 92 CPC refused as private

anchor.surface_text: An application to the Advocate-General for sanction to institute a suit under section92 of the Code of Civil Procedure was also refused for the same reason.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit for declaration that Thakurdwara is public temple

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed the suit, out of which the present appeal arises, for a declaration that the Thakurdwara is a public temple in which all the Hindus have a right to worship.

facts.text: First defendant contested suit claiming Thakurdwara and idols are private

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant contested the suit, and claimed that the Thakurdwara and the idols were private, and that the general public had no right to make any interference.

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge Sitapur dismissed suit holding private temple for family worship

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur, who tried the suit was of the opinion that the Thakurdwara had been built by Sheo Ghulam for worship by his family, and that it was a private temple. He accordingly dismissed the suit.

facts.text: District Judge Sitapur affirmed dismissal on appeal

anchor.surface_text: This judgment was affirmed on appeal by the District Judge, Sitapur, whose decision again was affirmed by the Chief Court of Oudh in second appeal.

facts.text: Chief Court of Oudh affirmed in second appeal and granted certificate under s.109 CPC

anchor.surface_text: This judgment was affirmed on appeal by the District Judge, Sitapur, whose decision again was affirmed by the Chief Court of Oudh in second appeal. The learned Judges, however, granted a certificate under s. 109 c  of the Code of Civil Procedure

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam had no male issue

anchor.surface_text: The will begins with the recital that the testator has two wives and no male issue, that he has constructed a Thakurdwara and installed the idol of Sri Radhakrishnaji therein,

facts.text: Will Exhibit A-1 dedicates immovable property to Sri Radhakrishnaji, wives as Mutawallis

anchor.surface_text: Clause I of Exhibit A-1 provides that after the death of the testator in the absence of male issue, the entire immovable property given below existing at present or which may come into being hereafter shall stand endowed in the name of Sri Radhakrisbnan,

facts.text: Committee of four persons appointed for management, two non-relations

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 appoints a committee of four persons to look after the , management of the temple and its properties, and of these, two are no relations of the testator and belong to a different caste.

facts.text: Public worshipped in temple freely without interference

anchor.surface_text: The witnesses examined on his behalf deposed that the villagers were worshipping in the temple freely and without any interference, and indeed, it was even stated that the Thakurdwara was built by Sheo Ghulam at the instance of the villagers,

facts.text: Consecration and installation ceremonies performed with great solemnity per Sastras

anchor.surface_text: it is common ground that the consecration of the temple and the installation of the idol of Sri Radhakrishnaji were made with great solemnity and in accordance with the Sastras.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Thakurdwara is public temple

anchor.surface_text: Having considered all the aspects, we are of opinion that the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

arguments.claim: Question whether public or private endowment is mixed question of law and fact, reviewable

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in this appeal whether the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji at Bhadesia is a public endowment or a private one is one of mixed law and fact...

arguments.claim: Distinction private vs public: specific individuals vs general public/class

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between a private and a public trust is that whereas in the former the beneficiaries are specific individuals, in the latter they are the general public or a class thereof.

arguments.claim: Cardinal point: intention of founder for specific individuals or general public

anchor.surface_text: the cardinal point to be decided is whether it was the intention of the founder that specified individuals are to have the right of worship at the shrine, or the general public...

arguments.claim: Will discloses intention for public dedication: recital no male issue indicates not family

anchor.surface_text: We think that the will read as a whole indubitably reveals an intention... The testator begins by stating that he had no male issue. In Nabi Shirazi... circumstance... suggests... not... family institution.

arguments.claim: Will: committee of management includes strangers, inconsistent with private family

anchor.surface_text: Then we have clause 2... constitutes a committee... two of whom were wholly unrelated... difficult to believe... intended to restrict... to his relations... entrusted... to strangers.

arguments.claim: Will clause 6 bars heirs, scant solicitude for relations, not for family benefit

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, there is clause 6... relationship... not particularly cordial... inconceivable... with such scant solicitude... would have endowed a temple for their benefit.

arguments.claim: Will contemplates perpetual continuance beyond wives' life, must be for public

anchor.surface_text: ...clear... testator contemplated continuance... beyond lifetime of his wives... necessary to hold... dedicated for worship by members of the public, and not merely of his family.

arguments.claim: Public user without interference cogent evidence of public dedication

anchor.surface_text: ...proof of user by the public without interference would be cogent evidence that the dedication was in favour of the public.

arguments.claim: User evidence consistent with public, not mere grace; pujari act respect not denial

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this fact does not afford sufficient ground... public worship... as a matter of right... act of the pujari... expression of regard... cannot be construed as denial.

arguments.claim: Distinction from Babu Bhagwan Din: here initial dedication to idol, user supports public

anchor.surface_text: ...relied on... Babu Bhagwan Din... but in present case, endowment in favour of idol... proof of user... cogent evidence... In Mundancheri... justified in presuming... public...

arguments.claim: Prathista ceremonies per Sastras valuable evidence of public dedication

anchor.surface_text: ...clear from texts that Prathista takes the place of Uthsarga in dedication of temples, and that there was Prathista... not in dispute. In our opinion, this establishes... public.

arguments.claim: Separate building, permanent idols, archaka puja, built for villagers indicate public

anchor.surface_text: We may now refer to certain facts... idol... separate building... factor... deciding... location inside private house or public... idols permanently installed... consistent with public...

arguments.claim: Lower court view that for family goes beyond pleadings and not supported by evidence

anchor.surface_text: The view of the lower court that the temple must be taken to have been dedicated to the members of the family goes beyond the pleading, and is not supported by the evidence...

holdings.text: The Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

anchor.surface_text: Having considered all the aspects, we are of opinion that the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will discloses public intention (no issue, stranger committee, perpetual continuance barring heirs); public user without interference; Prathista ceremonies per Sastras; separate building, permanent idols, archaka puja, built for villagers.

holdings.text: The Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji at Bhadesia is a public endowment or a private one is one of mixed law and fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings of fact binding but conclusion on dedication is proposition of law derived from facts; open to review per Lakshmidhar Misra.

holdings.text: The question whether the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji at Bhadesia is a public endowment or a private one is one of mixed law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: is one of mixed law and fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Essentially mixed; scope of dedication treated as law applied to facts; reviewable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapprehension: was Prasadothsarga not Uthsarga; Uthsarga for charities not temples; Prathista substitutes for temples and was performed.

holdings.text: The question of inferring a dedication to the public by reason of the performance of the Uthsarga ceremony cannot arise in the case of temples.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question of inferring a dedication to the public by reason of the performance of the Uthsarga ceremony cannot arise in the case of temples.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per texts (Mayukha, Kane); Prathista takes place of Uthsarga for temples; establishes public dedication here.

anchor.surface_text: In Lakshmidhar Misra v. Rang-alal 1 , in which the question was whether certain lands had been dedicated as cremation ground, it was observed by the Privy Council that it was essentially a mixed question of law and fact, and that while the findings of fact of the lower appellate companyrt must be accepted as binding, its actual

precedents.cited_proposition: question whether certain lands had been dedicated as cremation ground is essentially a mixed question of law and fact, and conclusion that there has been a dedication is a proposition of law derived from facts

anchor.surface_text: In Bhupati Nath Smritititha v. Ram Lal Maitra 1 , it was held on a companysideration of these and other texts that a gift to an idol was number to be judged by the rules applicable to a transfer to a sentient being, and that dedication of properties to an idol companysisted in the abandonment by the owner of his dominion over them for the purpose of their being appropriated for the purposes which he intends. Thus, it was observed by Sir Lawrence Jenkins C. J. at p. 138 that the pious purpose is still the legate, the establishment of the image is merely the mode in which the pious purpose is to be effected and that the dedication to a deity may be a companypendious expression of the pious purposes for which the dedication is designed. Vide also the observations of Sir Ashutosh Mookerjee at p. 155.

precedents.case_name: Bhupati Nath Smrititirtha v. Ram Lal Maitra
precedents.cited_proposition: a gift to an idol consisted in the abandonment by the owner of his dominion over properties for pious purposes; dedication to a deity expresses pious purposes

anchor.surface_text: In Hindu Religious Endowments Board v. Yeeraraghavachariar 2 , Varadachariar J. dealing with this question, referred to the decision in Bhupati Nath Smrititirtha v. Ram Lal Maitra supra and observed As explained in that case, the purpose of making a gift to a temple is number to companyfer a benefit on God but to companyfer a benefit on those who worship in that temple, by making it possible for them to have the worship companyducted in a proper and impressive manner. This is the sense in which a temple and its endowments are regarded as a public trust.

precedents.case_name: Hindu Religious Endowments Board v. Yeeraraghavachariar
precedents.cited_proposition: purpose of gift to temple is to confer benefit on worshippers, not on God; temple endowments regarded as public trust for benefit of worshippers

precedents.citation: Nabi Shirazi v. Province of Bengal supra

anchor.surface_text: In Nabi Shirazi v. Province of Bengal supra , the question was whether a wakf created by a deed of the year 1806 was a public or a private endowment. Referring to a recital in the deed that the settlor had numberchildren, Khundkar J. observed at p. 217 The deed recites that the founder has neither children number grandchildren, a circumstance which in itself suggests that the imambara was number to remain a private or family institution. Vide also the observations of Mitter J. at p. 228.

precedents.case_name: Nabi Shirazi v. Province of Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: recital that founder has no children or grandchildren suggests endowment not private or family institution but public

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Chief Court also relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroon 1 as an authority for the position that the mere fact that the public is allowed to visit a temple or thakurdwara cannot necessarily indicate that the trust is public as opposed to private. In that case, certain properties were granted number in favour of an idol or temple but in favour of one Daryao Gir, who was maintaining a temple and to his heirs in perpetuity.

precedents.case_name: Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Sarup
precedents.cited_proposition: mere fact that public allowed to worship in temple does not prove public dedication if grant initially to individual and family

anchor.surface_text: In Mundancheri Koman v. Achuthan 2 , which was referred to and followed in Babu Bhagwan Din v Gir Har Saroon 1 , the distinction between user in respect of an institution which is initially proved to have been private and one which is number, is thus expressed Had there been any sufficient reason for holding that these temples and their endowment were originally dedicated for the tarwad, and so were private trusts, their Lordships would have been slow to hold that the admission of the public in later times possibly owing to altered companyditions, would affect the private character of the trusts.

precedents.cited_proposition: public user does not convert private endowment to public if originally private; but if origin unclear, public user presumes public trust

anchor.surface_text: And as pointed out in Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan 1 , it is a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether an endowment is private or public, whether the place of worship is located inside a private house or a public building.

precedents.case_name: Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: whether place of worship located inside private house or public building is factor in deciding if endowment private or public

justification_sets.label: Distinction between Private and Public Religious Endowments support
